Introduction
Robert Soreng currently works at the Department of Botany, Smithsonian Institution. Robert does research in Botany, Evolutionary Biology and Systematics (Taxonomy). If you wish to contact him please write directly to sorengr@si.edu. He also helps maintain Poaceae data in Tropicos.org for other pdf files see https://repository.si.edu/handle/10088/2471

Projects (10)
Grasses of the Drakensberg Mountain Centre, Southern Africa: Knowledge-building for socio-ecological resilience
Project
High-elevation grasslands of southern Africa, renowned for their high endemism and diversity of ecosystem services, are socio-ecological systems that have seen human activity for millennia, but are currently threatened by poor land management practices and climate change. Controversy over their natural state has also led to conflicting policies and management emphases. While research on human and climatic influence on these grasslands is growing, there is still poor baseline knowledge on the crucial ecosystem-modulating component, grasses (Poaceae). Even the Drakensberg Mountain Centre (DMC) – perhaps the most-studied mountain system in the region – has very poor grass spatial data coverage and unresolved taxonomic issues. Given current severe habitat degradation from communal rangeland systems, this project seeks to combine taxonomic expertise in grasses with ecological research on the response of DMC grasslands to human impact and climate change. We hypothesise that high grass diversity & endemism firmly establishes the old-growth grasslands of the DMC as natural, although under tremendous pressure from direct human impact and climate change. Grass species associations will be recorded from different ecotopes along elevational gradients and across a range of grazing and fire regimes to document relationships between abiotic conditions, disturbance, and taxonomic, phylogenetic and functional diversity and composition. Global comparisons will then be made with datasets from the Andean puna and páramo and Hengduan mountains which found contrasting ecosystem responses to human disturbance that were often radically different from preconceived ideas. This research, combined with capacity building, will provide a broader perspective on naturalness, human impact and climate change on montane ecosystems while improving baseline knowledge on the grass species of high-elevation southern Africa, their ecology and conservation.

Understanding the páramo grasslands of Boyacá through building knowledge of grasses
Project
Grasses build and modulate entire ecosystems. Knowledge of grass species is thus essential to understand the function of grass-dominated ecosystems such as the páramos. Colombia’s páramos are unique, not just for their high diversity and endemism, but also for having evolved without significant grazing or fire disturbance, thus creating an endemic flora potentially more susceptible to anthropogenic disturbance. Studies documenting anthropogenic impact on natural grasslands rich in endemic species are still lacking, confounded by poor baseline knowledge on the crucial ecosystem component, grasses. This project will combine ecological research on páramo disturbance with taxonomic research on grasses, with special focus on grasslands harbouring endemic species. Grass species associations will be recorded across a range of grazing and fire regimes to document the relationship between disturbance and páramo grass composition. Grasses will be collected and identified using the best international herbarium collections. Specimen identification work will be carried out at UPTC and FMB, as well as other Colombian herbaria, to produce grass checklists for the Boyacán páramos and build new taxonomic knowledge. This research, combined with capacity building, will improve baseline knowledge on the grasses of Boyacá, their ecology and conservation, and will enable the future development of grass and páramo research in Boyacá.
